Authors: D.L., Nguyen Thi, Dieu Linh; T., Kieu-Xuan, Thuc; T.S., Bui, Tien Son; L.T., Le, Lanh Thanh; V.C., Pham, Van Cu
Author full names: Nguyen Thi, Dieu Linh (59213331700); Kieu-Xuan, Thuc (58406622500); Bui, Tien Son (59213331800); Le, Lanh Thanh (57207998682); Pham, Van Cu (57202577431)
Title: Towards interworking of matter and oneM2M: Design and implementation of a matter–oneM2M Interworking Proxy Entity
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Industry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dong Nai Technology University, Bien Hoa, Viet Nam; Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen Thi, Dieu Linh, Hanoi University of Industry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kieu-Xuan, Thuc, Hanoi University of Industry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Tien Son, Hanoi University of Industry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Lanh Thanh, Faculty of Information Technology, Dong Nai Technology University, Bien Hoa, Viet Nam; Pham, Van Cu, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Abstract: The new smart home protocol, Matter, has garnered worldwide attention for its ability to tackle the most significant obstacle to fully unlock the potential of smart homes: interoperability. The increasing support for Matter among numerous vendors in their products is having a noticeable impact on interoperability at the device level. This work expands the reach of Matter to the IoT platform level by integrating it with an open and standardized platform, oneM2M. One of the key strengths of oneM2M is its ability to provide an open, common, and flexible interface at the platform level, facilitating seamless interconnection across various domains. This integration pave the way to provide Matter's smart homes user with advanced intelligence services, including AI/ML applications, and emerging concepts like the metaverse. The proposed Interworking Proxy Entity (IPE) for Matter has been successfully implemented, and multiple scenarios have been tested using both commercial and experimental Matter devices within the oneM2M ACME and Mobius platforms. The results demonstrate seamless integration of Matter devices into the oneM2M platform, enabling other applications to interact with them solely through oneM2M standard interfaces. Additionally, the IPE proves to be practical for real-world applications with negligible overhead, offering mutual benefits for both Matter and oneM2M ecosystems. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Interworking Proxy Entity; Matter; Onem2m; Onem2m–matter Interoperability

Authors: T.Q., Ho, Thong Quoc; L.T.P., Nguyen, Linh T.P.; U., Grote, Ulrike; D.B., Rahut, Dil Bahadur; T., Sonobe, Tetsushi; T.T., Nguyen, Trung Thanh
Author full names: Ho, Thong Quoc (56822933400); Nguyen, Linh T.P. (59239242600); Grote, Ulrike (6603356129); Rahut, Dil Bahadur (56962787600); Sonobe, Tetsushi (7005665322); Nguyen, Trung Thanh (56000733000)
Title: Gender and generosity: How contribution information triggers solidarity behavior during a crisis
Source title: Journal of Behavioral and Experimental Economics
Affiliations: University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; VNUHCM-University of Economics and Law, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ho, Thong Quoc, School of Economics, University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Linh T.P., VNUHCM-University of Economics and Law, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Grote, Ulrike, Institute for Environmental Economics and World Trade, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany; Rahut, Dil Bahadur, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Sonobe, Tetsushi, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen, Trung Thanh, School of Economics, University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Institute for Environmental Economics and World Trade, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Universität Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic has shown how important solidarity and prosocial behavior are in society. However, it is not well understood how solidarity behavior can be encouraged in such extreme cases. This study investigates the effect of activating crisis concerns and contribution information on solidarity perception and behavior using an experimental survey of 1,259 respondents in 2022 from Vietnam. Our findings reveal that (i) there exists a perception-actual behavior gap as the available information is not able to promote solidarity behavior, (ii) activating concerns about the impact of a crisis, i.e., COVID-19, does not trigger prosocial perception and behavior, (iii) contribution information improves solidarity perception, and (iv) females tend to donate more than their male counterparts. When aiming to promote solidarity behavior, it is important to be aware of the prosocial perception-behavior gap, and consider different strategies for males and females, including paying more attention to evoking moral emotions in women. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Covid-19; Crisis; Gender; Solidarity Behavior; Solidarity Perception

Authors: W., Kodama, Wataru; P.J., Morgan, Peter John; D., Azhgaliyeva, Dina; T., Long, Trinhquang; K., Kim, Kunhyui
Author full names: Kodama, Wataru (57457953000); Morgan, Peter John (52264423300); Azhgaliyeva, Dina (56197045500); Long, Trinhquang (57203819393); Kim, Kunhyui (59992557300)
Title: Family business during the COVID-19 pandemic in Asia: Role of government financial aid and coping strategies
Affiliations: Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Georg-August-Universität Göttingen, Gottingen, Germany; Banking University - Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kodama, Wataru, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan, Georg-August-Universität Göttingen, Gottingen, Germany; Morgan, Peter John, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Azhgaliyeva, Dina, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Long, Trinhquang, Banking University - Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kim, Kunhyui, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic has heavily affected economic activities. In emerging Asia, where small family businesses play central roles in their economies, previous studies found that the sector was particularly hard hit by the pandemic. However, little is known about how households have mitigated the negative shocks on their family business during the pandemic. Using datasets from representative household surveys in seventeen Asian countries from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) regions, this study investigates the role of business coping strategies and government financial aid in mitigating the adverse impacts of the pandemic on family business conditions in the short run. We find that (i) adoption of coping strategy is associated with a lower probability of both a decline in family business income and family business closure; and (ii) government financial aid is associated with a lower probability of a decline in family business income and a higher probability of adopting coping strategies. This study is one of the first to provide empirical evidence on mitigation mechanisms of family business in emerging Asia. This is important to understand what policies will enable the family business sector to perform better during the future pandemics and other economic crises. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Matsumoto, Shigeru; V.N., Hoang, Viet Ngu; C.E., Wilson, Clevo E.
Author full names: Matsumoto, Shigeru (36646475900); Hoang, Viet Ngu (35310351200); Wilson, Clevo E. (7404894763)
Title: Covid-19 lockdown, gender and income dynamics in household energy consumption: evidence from Japan
Affiliations: Aoyama Gakuin University, Tokyo, Japan; Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Matsumoto, Shigeru, Faculty of Economics, Aoyama Gakuin University, Tokyo, Japan; Hoang, Viet Ngu, School of Economics and Finance, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia, International School, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Wilson, Clevo E., School of Economics and Finance, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane, Australia
Abstract: Residential electricity consumption and time spent at home by household members increased while household income decreased during the COVID-19 pandemic restrictions. Using survey data of Japanese households purchasing electricity from the Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings, before and during the pandemic, we examine the various dynamics at play involving income, increased time spent at home by both partners and the role of genders in energy consumption. Results show a positive relationship between changes in electricity consumption and changes in household income, suggesting that households reduced their electricity usage following a decrease in income. Interestingly, the results also show that consumption changes are positively correlated to changes in hours spent at home by working husbands but negatively correlated to changes in the hours spent at home by working wives. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Khieu, Hoang; R., León-González, Roberto
Author full names: Khieu, Hoang (57194700715); León-González, Roberto (6506528860)
Title: THE WEALTH DISTRIBUTION IN A PRECAUTIONARY SAVINGS MODEL WITH CAPITAL INCOME RISK
Affiliations: Fulbright University, Viet Nam, Viet Nam; National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies, Minato, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Khieu, Hoang, Fulbright University, Viet Nam, Viet Nam; León-González, Roberto, National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies, Minato, Japan
Abstract: Explaining the evolution of the wealth distribution requires understanding the dynamics of consumption and savings. We analyze the dynamics of consumption and savings under uncertainty in labour income and the rate of return on wealth, which are two-state continuous time Markov processes. The rate of return is persistent and has a right-skewed distribution. We show that the wealth accumulation process has a stationary distribution if the (unconditional) expected change in the rate of return is sufficiently small or large. In particular, when the expected change in the rate of return is moderate, the wealth accumulation process is non-stationary. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Capital And Labour Income Risk; Dynamics Of Wealth And Consumption; Precautionary Savings; Stationary Wealth Distribution

Authors: D.K., Behera, Deepak Kumar; D.B., Rahut, Dil Bahadur; U., Dash, Umakant
Author full names: Behera, Deepak Kumar (56959992500); Rahut, Dil Bahadur (56962787600); Dash, Umakant (26657101700)
Title: Fiscal Policy Determinants of Health Spending in India: State Versus Center
Affiliations: RMIT University Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Institute of Rural Management Anand, Anand, India
Authors with affiliations: Behera, Deepak Kumar, Department of Economics and Finance, RMIT University Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Rahut, Dil Bahadur, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Dash, Umakant, Institute of Rural Management Anand, Anand, India
Abstract: This study uses data from 1986 to 2021 and the auto-regressive distributed lag model to explore India’s fiscal policy determinants of government health spending. The results find two structural breaks in time: (i) 2002 for state government health spending (SGHS) and (ii) 2014 for central government health spending. The results also show that central revenue transfers to states have a positive and statistically significant effect on SGHS in the long run. The results imply that a 1% rise in central revenue transfers to states leads to a 0.399% increase in SGHS. Further, state government public debt exhibits a negative and statistically significant relationship with SGHS, implying that a 1% rise in public debt leads to a 0.119% fall in SGHS in the long run. Fiscal management (i.e., revenue mobilization and debt sustainability) is essential to prepare a long-term strategy for health-care financing. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

(7401451781); Lersvanichkool, Ackadech (57130926200); Bui, Van Hanh (59224167400); Tanaka, Manabu (25641191700)
Title: Elucidation of droplet detachment mechanism in metal-cored arc welding
Affiliations: Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; CSIRO Manufacturing, Australia; Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Tashiro, Shinichi, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Trinh, Quang Ngoc, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Dang Khoi, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Suga, Tetsuo, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Kakizaki, Tomonori, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Yamazaki, Kei, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Murphy, Anthony B., CSIRO Manufacturing, Australia; Lersvanichkool, Ackadech, Ltd., Bangkok, Thailand; Bui, Van Hanh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tanaka, Manabu, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: It has been demonstrated experimentally that a globular transfer mode tends to occur in argon gas metal arc welding using a metal-cored wire (called metal-red arc welding (MCAW)) even under conditions where a spray transfer mode occurs when a solid wire is used. This study aimed to elucidate the droplet detachment mechanism in MCAW using numerical simulations. It was observed that in the initial stage of droplet growth, the argon arc attachment (which carried a large portion of the current) was located on the metal sheath surrounding the unmelted flux. Moreover, an eddy containing an upward flow at the wire axis was formed inside the droplet. When this eddy was formed, the droplet volume increased owing to wire melting. However, neck formation did not occur. This is considered to be because only a small portion of the current is conducted through the droplet, and the Lorentz force acting on the droplet is significantly weak. Thereafter, when the droplet grew to a certain extent and the arc attachment moved below the unmelted flux position, the Lorentz force acted strongly and almost uniformly on the droplet. Accordingly, this eddy disappeared, and the flow abruptly transitioned to a downward unidirectional high-speed flow. Consequently, the droplet began to extend downward to form a neck, which caused it to detach. For these reasons, the time required for droplet detachment increased, and the metal transfer frequency decreased compared with the case of the solid wire. This explains the observation that globular transfer persists in metal-cored wires at currents higher than those for which the transition to spray transfer has occurred for solid wires. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Trinh, Ngoc Quang (57225041555); Le, Khoidang (59161737700); Tashiro, Shinichi (58894306600); Suga, Tetsuo (7201431992); Sasakura, Shuji (55694373200); Fukuda, Kazuhiro (59181172200); Murphy, Anthony B. (7401451781); van Bui, Hanh (57209322828); Tanaka, Manabu (25641191700)
Title: Optimization of metal transfer in rutile flux-cored arc welding through controlled CO2 concentration in argon–CO2 shielding gas
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; CSIRO Manufacturing, Clayton, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Trinh, Ngoc Quang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Khoidang, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Tashiro, Shinichi, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Suga, Tetsuo, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Sasakura, Shuji, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Fukuda, Kazuhiro, Kobe Steel, Ltd., Kobe, Japan; Murphy, Anthony B., CSIRO Manufacturing, Clayton, Australia; van Bui, Hanh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tanaka, Manabu, Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: In this study, we analyzed the impact of carbon dioxide concentration in argon–carbon dioxide shielding gas on droplet transfer characteristics in rutile flux-cored arc welding, employing titanium oxide as a primary wire flux component. The welding process was carried out at a welding current of 190, 220, 250, 280, and 310 A under an argon–CO<inf>2</inf> shielding gas mixture with six levels of CO<inf>2</inf> concentration of 0, 5 %, 10 %, 15 %, 20 %, and 25 % for a parametric study. Unlike the conventional solid wire welding trend, where the droplet transfer frequency decreases with the increase in carbon dioxide concentration, an increase in metal transfer frequency was observed with the increase in CO<inf>2</inf> concentration from approximately 5 % to 20 %. The concentration reaching the maximum frequency was 20 % at 190 A, which decreased as the welding current increased, reaching 5 % at 310 A. Droplet initiation at the lower sheath end is succeeded by a gradual downward movement along the flux column's side after a few milliseconds. Upon reaching the lower end, the droplet forms a neck and undergoes separation. Thus, the length of the flux column directly impacts the duration of one droplet transfer cycle. The length was decreased by arc constriction when increasing CO<inf>2</inf> concentration appropriately to concentrate beneath the flux column or by increasing the welding current to raise the arc temperature, which contributed to melting and shortening the flux column. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H.T., Bui, Huong T.; L.H., Pham, Long Hong; N.L.T., Pham, Ngoc Linh Thi; D.T.P., Anh, Dang Thi Phuong; Q.N., Bui, Quynh Ngoc; D.T., Nguyen, Dung Tien; T.T., Duong, Thuy T.M.; C.H., Nguyen, Chung H.; H., Saito, Hiroaki
Author full names: Bui, Huong T. (56120995300); Pham, Long Hong (57200893152); Pham, Ngoc Linh Thi (59078848300); Anh, Dang Thi Phuong (57311459700); Bui, Quynh Ngoc (57924627400); Nguyen, Dung Tien (57210580160); Duong, Thuy T.M. (57208585717); Nguyen, Chung H. (57195414551); Saito, Hiroaki (57193096174)
Title: Vietnam tourism at the crossroads of socialism and market economy
Affiliations: Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Sports and Tourism, Thai Binh, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Huong T., College of Sustainability and Tourism, Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Pham, Long Hong, Faculty of Tourism Studies, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Ngoc Linh Thi, Sports and Tourism, Thai Binh, Viet Nam; Anh, Dang Thi Phuong, Faculty of Tourism Studies, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Quynh Ngoc, Faculty of Tourism Studies, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Dung Tien, Faculty of Tourism Studies, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Duong, Thuy T.M., Faculty of Geography, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Chung H., Faculty of Pedagogy, Hanoi University of Education, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Saito, Hiroaki, College of International Management, Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan
Abstract: Purpose: Vietnam has repositioned itself from a war-torn country to a popular tourist destination. Although research on Vietnam tourism has grown in number, a macro analysis of national tourism governance and policies has largely been missing. Design/methodology/approach: This synthesis paper offers a systemic analysis of Vietnam’s tourism accommodating intensified government intervention and dramatic market changes in recent decades. The authors offer a chronological analysis of tourism development along with the major political and economic turns of the country. Findings: The patterns of tourism development reflect a compromise between centralization and decentralization of the governance system and a trade-off between economic and social objectives of development. Balancing these opposites, the internal strength of the domestic market and the resilience of communities and businesses become key assets for growth in circumstances where the socialist market economy continues to inform the current and future development of the industry. Research limitations/implications: Although the case of Vietnam is unique, the adaptive mechanism of the tourism industry highlighted in this paper offers a useful lesson for other developing countries. The research addresses tourism in the political economy in developing countries, which is valuable for researchers, policy analysts as well as practitioners in tourism. Practical implications: The practical contribution of the study is derived from authors’ academic and industrial backgrounds. Findings from the study serve as a useful reference for those who embark on the study of tourism governance and policy-making in developing countries and problems associated with the economic transitional process. Those problems of the disparity between centralization and decentralization of the political system might not be only significant in Vietnam, but also prevail in developing countries. Thus, this study offers a point of departure for future empirical and comparative research on the kindship of tourism and political economy in a full scale. Social implications: The transitional economy as viewed through the tourism industry is prominently presented in the “evolutionary” approach to the transitional economy, which exhibits several unique features: the transition from a centrally planned (command) economy to a market economy and the manifestations of a socialist orientation in the modern economic management system (Vuong et al., 2019). While data from this study is mainly illustrative of the first point, the transition from a planned economy to a market economy, the second characteristic, the manifestation of a social orientation has only slightly been addressed and will need further elaboration in a future study. While Vietnam’s tourism positions itself in a socialist market-oriented economy might set a unique case, the study highlights the politics of tourism is shaped by the politico-economic system. The authors conclude that the adaptation of Vietnam tourism to a socialist market-orientated economy is better perceived as a social evolution achievement rather than a feature of capitalism. Originality/value: The latest study on tourism governance (Bui et al., 2022) has outlined the evolution of the tourism administrative system and markets in the country; however, linkages of tourism to the broader political economic system have yet to be addressed. Addressing this gap, the authors carry out analysis of policies and governance from the insider’s viewpoint, when team members have been involved in numerous tourism planning and development projects, both on international and national scales. The practical experience along with thorough review of literature and statistical data contributes to shaping a fresh understanding of tourism in a transitional economy. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Centralization; Decentralization; Governance; Planning; Socialist Market Economy
Funding Texts: The project is funded through Japan Society for Promotion of Sciences, grant number 22H03859.

Authors: B., Nghiêm-Phú, Bình; T.T., Hoàng-Thi, Thu Trang; L.H., Vu, Lan Huong
Author full names: Nghiêm-Phú, Bình (56386139600); Hoàng-Thi, Thu Trang (59212874300); Vu, Lan Huong (59002917900)
Title: The challenges and negotiation methods of relationship management in internships: A collaborative autoethnography of university staff in Vietnam
Affiliations: University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nghiêm-Phú, Bình, School of Economics and Management, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Hoàng-Thi, Thu Trang, Faculty of Hospitality and Tourism, Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Lan Huong, Faculty of Hospitality and Tourism, Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Universities worldwide, including Vietnam, are incorporating internship programs into their curriculums. These programs involve the students as internal customers and the business partners as external customers. However, previous studies have yet to examine the management of the relationships with these customers and the logistics of the internship programs. Without this understanding, the internship management and preparation processes may be difficult or inadequate. Therefore, this chapter reports a study investigating the challenges in relationship management in internships and the methods adopted to negotiate with these challenges. The study employed the information provided by two faculty members at a public university in Vietnam via a collaborative autoethnography. This information was also aligned with the existing literature as a validation tactic. The findings revealed a management process of 20 steps and four phases. Each step's challenges (e.g., late responses, sudden cancellation, and agreement violations) and negotiation methods (e.g., backup plans, crisis management, activeness, and flexibility) were detailed. The fundamental logistics functions, including information handling, inventory, packaging, and transportation, were linked to the phases. The chapter then discussed these findings to build up a theory about educational internship logistics and provide some implications for better managing the internship programs. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Collaborative Autoethnography; Education Logistics; Internship; Relationship Management; Vietnam

Authors: H.T., Nguyen-Phung, Hang Thu; H., Le, Hai
Author full names: Nguyen-Phung, Hang Thu (57983679800); Le, Hai (57397171800)
Title: Urbanization and Health Expenditure: An Empirical Investigation from Households in Vietnam
Affiliations: Asian Growth Research Institute, Fukuoka, Japan; Hanoi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; FPT University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen-Phung, Hang Thu, Division of Research, Asian Growth Research Institute, Fukuoka, Japan, Faculty of Information Technology, Hanoi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Hai, Department of Business, FPT University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study examines the effects of urbanization on household health expenditure. Using a unique bi-annually household-level dataset from 2012–2016 from Vietnam, we obtain key findings as follows. To mitigate possible endogeneity concerns, we utilize a two-stage least squares regression (2SLS) approach, employing the development of information and communication (ICT) infrastructure at the province level as an instrumental variable (IV). The key findings can be summarized as follows. First, urbanization significantly reduces Vietnamese households’ inpatient and outpatient health expenses. Second, the self-treatment expenses of households increase as the process of urbanization advances. In addition, we perform various robustness checks, encompassing different measures of urbanization, the use of lag of urbanization as an additional IV, and the plausible exogenous IV. The outcomes derived from these rigorous sensitivity analyses substantiate the reliability and consistency of our key results. Finally, we propose different ways to explain these results, including health insurance expenses and household income. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Health Expenditure; Health Insurance; Ict; Instrumental Variable; Urbanization; Vhlss

Authors: P.P., Ngoc, Pham Phuong; H., Lee, Hanol; D., Wie, Dainn
Author full names: Ngoc, Pham Phuong (58341849200); Lee, Hanol (57189692615); Wie, Dainn (55675731900)
Title: Trade liberalization and women's marriage and fertility decisions in Vietnam
Affiliations: Diplomatic Academy of Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Southwestern University of Finance and Economics, Chengdu, China; National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies, Minato, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ngoc, Pham Phuong, Diplomatic Academy of Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Lee, Hanol, Southwestern University of Finance and Economics, Chengdu, China; Wie, Dainn, National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies, Minato, Japan
Abstract: This study investigates the impact of a large demand shock driven by the US-Vietnam Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA) in 2001 on the timing of women's marital decisions and first childbirth experiences in Vietnam. We hypothesize that the reduction in women's and men's self-employment would delay family formation and childbirth, with the ultimate impact on marriage remaining ambiguous. Analyzing data from the Vietnam Household Living Standards Surveys, we find that both men and women are less likely to be self-employed in the face of a substantial trade shock. Notably, the decreasing impact on women's self-employment becomes more pronounced than that for men post-2012, a decade after the agreement's enforcement. Employing the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey and survival analysis, we empirically demonstrate that increased exposure to trade postpones women's timing of marriage and first childbirth. On average, in 2013, the BTA resulted in a 7.39- and 7.42 %-point decrease in the probability of entering marriage and becoming a mother, respectively. We also present suggestive evidence that increased exposure to trade liberalization eventually increases the likelihood of marriage and the number of children among women over 40. The findings in this study imply that policy promoting trade liberalization should consider its extensive impacts on young labor force's family formation through change in their individual economic prospects. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Delayed Fertility; Marriage And Fertility In Vietnam; Marriage Timing; Reproductive Decision-making; Trade Liberalization

Authors: M.T.T., Nguyen, Minh Thu Thi
Author full names: Nguyen, Minh Thu Thi (57220184323)
Title: Provincial income convergence in Vietnam: spatio-temporal dynamics and conditioning factors
Affiliations: Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Minh Thu Thi, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan, Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this article, we use a three-step procedure that combines the log t convergence test, Explanatory Spatial Data Analysis, and ordered logit regression to determine the spatio-temporal dynamics and determinants of provincial income clustering in Vietnam during the 2010–2020 period. Our findings are three-fold. First, provincial income clustering in Vietnam follows patterns of club convergence towards multiple equilibria. Seven convergence clubs encompassing 61 provinces are identified. Second, spatial autocorrelation encourages neighboring provinces to converge toward shared income equilibria. High-income clusters are observed in the Northern and Southern Key Economic Regions, while low-income clusters are concentrated in the mountainous areas of Northern Vietnam. Finally, both internal and external factors significantly affect the formation of convergence clubs. Vital internal factors include localities’ initial conditions of physical capital and structural change. Meanwhile, external factors refer to spatial externalities among neighboring provinces. We highlight spatial complementarity in physical capital accumulation and spatial competition in industrial intensification among neighboring provinces. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Club Convergence; Income Clustering; O40; O47; R10; R11; Spatial Dependence; Spatial Externalities; Structural Changes; Vietnam

Authors: H., Pham, Hien; T., Yamashita, Takuro
Author full names: Pham, Hien (58062964500); Yamashita, Takuro (36159289900)
Title: Auction design with heterogeneous priors
Affiliations: National Economics University Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Hien, Faculty of Mathematical Economics, National Economics University Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yamashita, Takuro, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: We consider an auction design problem with private values, where the seller and bidders may enjoy heterogeneous priors about their (possibly correlated) valuations. Each bidder forms an (interim) belief about the others based on his own prior updated by observing his own value. If the seller faces uncertainty about the bidders' priors, even if he knows that the bidders' priors are within any given distance from his, he may find it worst-case optimal to propose a dominant-strategy auction mechanism. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Auction; Foundation For Dominant-strategy Mechanisms; Heterogeneous Prior; Robust Mechanism Design; Worst Case Guarantee

Authors: D.T.N., Huy, Dinh Tran Ngoc; V.Q., Nam, Vu Quynh; H.T., Hanh, Hoang Thanh; T.N., Nguyen, Thach Ngoc
Author full names: Huy, Dinh Tran Ngoc (36951633200); Nam, Vu Quynh (57247248200); Hanh, Hoang Thanh (57211475196); Nguyen, Thach Ngoc (57200036923)
Title: Further analysis of Bitcoin, Fintech, and P2P lending: Perspectives and recommendations from industry 4.0
Affiliations: Banking University - Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Academy of Policy and Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Banking University - Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Huy, Dinh Tran Ngoc, Banking University - Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nam, Vu Quynh, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Hanh, Hoang Thanh, Academy of Policy and Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thach Ngoc, Banking University - Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: In several countries in the world, Bitcoin and P2P lending have been accepted and developed strongly. This study aims to evaluate the suitability, pros, and cons of Bitcoin, Fintech, P2P lending, and its platform in emerging markets such as Vietnam. The research used qualitative analysis combined with data collection method published, statistics, analysis, synthesis, comparison, to generate qualitative comments and discussion; evaluate results, the article analyzed and evaluated the impacts of Fintech, P2P lending, and Bitcoin and virtual currency on society of Vietnam, both positive and negative sides. It was found that we need to improve regulations on Fintech and shadow banking to overcome the weaknesses of commercial banks, to reduce risks as many nations in the world accept it. Experiences of other countries such as the United States, Japan, China, or the developed countries of the European Union and consequences for the economy became a lesson for well as developing countries. Hence, we need to implement risk management plans to reduce technological and IT risks. Proper solutions and development orientation as well as risk management for Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies are suggested. Last but not least, the research was limited to the case of Vietnam; hence, we can expand research to other Asian countries or other emerging markets. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bitcoin; Cryptocurrencies; Fintech; Industry 4.0; P2p Lending; Vietnam; Virtual Currency

Authors: D.K., Behera, Deepak Kumar; D.B., Rahut, Dil Bahadur; M., Padmaja, M.; A.K., Dash, Ajit Kumar
Author full names: Behera, Deepak Kumar (56959992500); Rahut, Dil Bahadur (56962787600); Padmaja, M. (57211101093); Dash, Ajit Kumar (58913023600)
Title: Socioeconomic determinants of happiness: Empirical evidence from developed and developing countries
Source title: Journal of Behavioral and Experimental Economics
Affiliations: RMIT University Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; National Institute of Technology, Kuruskshetra, India; Birla Global University, Bhubaneswar, India
Authors with affiliations: Behera, Deepak Kumar, Department of Economics and Finance, RMIT University Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Rahut, Dil Bahadur, Asian Development Bank Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Padmaja, M., Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, National Institute of Technology, Kuruskshetra, India; Dash, Ajit Kumar, Department of Economics, Birla Global University, Bhubaneswar, India
Abstract: This study aims to understand the factors that contribute to people's happiness or life satisfaction in 166 countries (51 developed, 115 developing) from 2005 to 2020. The study considers the effects of various socioeconomic factors, such as per capita income, social support, freedom to make life choices, perception of corruption, air pollution exposure, and gender inequality, on the level of happiness. We used panel two-way robust fixed effects and panel quantile regression for empirical analysis. The results show that per capita income, social support, and freedom to make life choices positively impact happiness, while air pollution exposure has a negative impact. However, gender inequality does not significantly affect happiness levels. These findings highlight the relevance of the Easterlin Paradox, which suggests that income can mediate happiness by promoting emotional well-being, gender equality, and a clean environment. Therefore, policymakers should focus on creating a more holistic approach to improving the well-being and happiness of its citizens. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air Pollution Exposure; Easterlin Paradox; Freedom To Make Life Choices; Gender Inequality; Happiness Determinants; Social Support; Socioeconomic Factors

Authors: B.T.T., Dang, Binh Thi Thanh; T.X., Hoang, Trung Xuan
Author full names: Dang, Binh Thi Thanh (58965141000); Hoang, Trung Xuan (56293753400)
Title: The impact of compulsory primary education law on the educational attainment of children: Evidence from Vietnam
Affiliations: Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Dang, Binh Thi Thanh, Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan; Hoang, Trung Xuan, Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study examines the short-term impact of the compulsory primary education law (CPEL) on the educational attainment of children in Vietnam. This study uses the 1999 Vietnam Population and Housing Census and survival analysis to account for the right-censoring problem in the educational outcomes of children. The study found that CPEL reduces the dropout rate of children by 12%. However, the effect is minor, especially when compared with the impact of family income and parents' education. This finding is similar to those of other studies, suggesting that in addition to CPEL, other family income support and parent-oriented policies are crucial to improving children's educational attainment. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Children's Educational Attainment; Compulsory Education; Dropout Rate; Survival Analysis; Academic Performance; Child Development; Educational Attainment; Income Distribution; Primary Education; Social Policy; Socioeconomic Conditions; Viet Nam
Index Keywords: academic performance; child development; educational attainment; income distribution; primary education; social policy; socioeconomic conditions; Viet Nam

Authors: T.H., Le, Thai Ha; L.H., Vo, Long Hai; F., Taghizadeh-Hesary, Farhad
Author full names: Le, Thai Ha (56799783400); Vo, Long Hai (57209273981); Taghizadeh-Hesary, Farhad (56291956400)
Title: A study on the nonlinear dynamics of ASEAN financial integration
Source title: Journal of Asian Business and Economic Studies
Affiliations: VinFuture Foundation, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia; Tokai University, Tokyo, Japan; IPAG Business School, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Le, Thai Ha, VinFuture Foundation, Hanoi, Viet Nam, IPAG Business School, Paris, France; Vo, Long Hai, The University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia; Taghizadeh-Hesary, Farhad, Tokai University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Purpose: This study examines the co-integration relationships between Association of Southeast Nations (ASEAN) stock indices as a way to assess the feasibility of policy initiatives to strengthen market integration in ASEAN and identify implications for portfolio investors. Design/methodology/approach: The authors employ threshold co-integration tests and a non-linear autoregressive distributed lag (NARDL) model to study the asymmetric dynamics of ASEAN equity markets. The study’s data cover the 2009–2022 period for seven member states: Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam. Findings: The authors find evidence supporting co-integration relationships; adjustment toward equilibrium is asymmetric in the short run and symmetric in the long run for these countries. While co-movement in ASEAN equity markets seems encouraging for initiatives seeking to foster financial integration in regional economies, the benefits for international portfolio diversification appear to be neutralized. Originality/value: The issue of stock market integration is important among policymakers, investors and academics. This study examines the level of stock market integration in ASEAN during the 2009–2022 period. For this purpose, advanced co-integration techniques are applied to different frequencies of data (daily, weekly and monthly) for comparison and completeness. The empirical analysis of this study is conducted using the Enders and Siklos (2001) co-integration and threshold adjustment procedure. This advanced co-integration technique is superior compared to other co-integration techniques by permitting asymmetry in the adjustment toward equilibrium. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Asean; Nonlinear Ardl Model; Stock Market Integration; Threshold Co-integration
References: Aït-Sahalia, Yacine, The leverage effect puzzle: Disentangling sources of bias at high frequency, Journal of Financial Economics, 109, 1, pp. 224-249, (2013); Batten, Jonathan A., Time-varying energy and stock market integration in Asia, Energy Economics, 80, pp. 777-792, (2019); Bekaert, Geert, Time‐Varying World Market Integration, Journal of Finance, 50, 2, pp. 403-444, (1995); Bekaert, Geert, International stock return comovements, Journal of Finance, 64, 6, pp. 2591-2626, (2009); Proceedings of the American Statistical Association Business and Economic Statistics Section, (1976); Caporale, Guglielmo Maria, Global and regional stock market integration in Asia: A panel convergence approach, International Review of Financial Analysis, 65, (2019); Caporale, Guglielmo Maria, Stock Market Linkages between the Asean Countries, China and the US: A Fractional Integration/cointegration Approach, Emerging Markets Finance and Trade, 58, 5, pp. 1502-1514, (2022); Chen, Li Hsueh, A threshold cointegration analysis of asymmetric price transmission from crude oil to gasoline prices, Economics Letters, 89, 2, pp. 233-239, (2005); Chien, Meise, Dynamic Asian stock market convergence: Evidence from dynamic cointegration analysis among China and ASEAN-5, Economic Modelling, 51, pp. 84-98, (2015); Click, Reid W., Stock market integration in ASEAN after the Asian financial crisis, Journal of Asian Economics, 16, 1, pp. 5-28, (2005)

Authors: H., Suto, Hidetsugu; C., Tsunemi, Chie; P., Amatayakul, Patraree; K., Kojima, Kaori

Title: Introducing Bibliobattle into Japanese Language Class in Thailand
Affiliations: Kindai University, Higashiosaka, Japan; Thai-Nichi Institute of Technology, Bangkok, Thailand; Thai-Nichi Institute of Technology, Bangkok, Thailand; Hanoi Law University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Suto, Hidetsugu, Cyber Informatics Research Institute, Kindai University, Higashiosaka, Japan; Tsunemi, Chie, International Department of Japanese Language for International Business, Thai-Nichi Institute of Technology, Bangkok, Thailand; Amatayakul, Patraree, Japanese Department, Thai-Nichi Institute of Technology, Bangkok, Thailand; Kojima, Kaori, Hanoi Law University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this paper, a workshop, which is designed based on a gamification theory, for students who learn Japanese language is mentioned. In this workshop, the participants enjoy a book review match, Bibliobattle, and try to win an international Bibliobattle competition, The world Bibliobattle championship. The workshop was held from 26 July to 13 September 2023 in Bangkok, Thailand. First, the formal rules of Bibliobattle and practices in which Bibliobattle is played in language classes are shown as the backgrounds. Then, the outline of the workshop is mentioned. Questionnaires were conducted to investigate the effects of the workshop. The results show that the workshop effected positively on the attitudes for learning of the participants. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Kosuke, Tanizaki; F., Keisuke, Furumoto; M., Kohei, Masumi; H., Trong-Minh, Hoang; S., Yoshiaki, Shiraishi; T., Takeshi, Takahashi
Author full names: Kosuke, Tanizaki (59517737300); Keisuke, Furumoto (59517633900); Kohei, Masumi (59517536700); Trong-Minh, Hoang (59517536800); Yoshiaki, Shiraishi (59517737400); Takeshi, Takahashi (59517536900)
Title: Investigating Agricultural IoT Devices and Services from Cybersecurity Perspectives
Affiliations: Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Kosuke, Tanizaki, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Keisuke, Furumoto, National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Kohei, Masumi, National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan; Trong-Minh, Hoang, Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology Vietnam, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yoshiaki, Shiraishi, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Takeshi, Takahashi, National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, Koganei, Japan
Abstract: The rise of smart farm has led to the increasing use of devices with communication capabilities in the agricultural field. Although papers and security reports have warned about the necessity of security measures for IoT devices used in the industrial field, there is little existing research that investigates the actual state of these measures. In this paper, we first developed a list of 175 agricultural IoT devices, followed by a taxonomy based on that list. Next, using Shodan's observation network, we conducted a large-scale survey of agricultural IoT devices (including systems and services that include agricultural IoT devices within themselves) that are publicly available on the Internet to investigate the actual security of agricultural IoT devices. In addition, this study also examines security risks related to agricultural IoT devices that may emerge in the future and current standards that can be used as countermeasures. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Nghiêm-Phú, Bình; H.T.B., Trân, Hang Thi Bĺch
Author full names: Nghiêm-Phú, Bình (56386139600); Trân, Hang Thi Bĺch (57924781500)
Title: Public Opinion on Quarantine Hotels: a Question of Corporate Social Responsibility
Affiliations: University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nghiêm-Phú, Bình, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Trân, Hang Thi Bĺch, Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This chapter examines how hotel businesses in Vietnam overcome the challenges caused by COVID-19 by transforming their accommodation units into quarantine facilities. Analysing press and user-generated content, it was found that both positive and negative images were attached to the quarantine hotels and that attitudes changed over the course of the pandemic. The fndings demonstrated that corporate social responsibility (CSR) could be implemented to sustain businesses in the current circumstances while preparing for brand strengthening for recovery after the pandemic was over. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Traditional social norms and values in today’s business world: a study in Vietnam
Affiliations: University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Academy of Journalism and Communication, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nghiêm-Phú, Bình, School of Economics and Management, University of Hyogo, Kobe, Japan; Nguyễn, Thành Hưng, Thuongmai University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phạm-Lê, Dạ Hương, Academy of Journalism and Communication, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This chapter aims to examine how contemporary business students in Vietnam perceive the importance and relevance of the existing norms and values in their generation. An intracultural approach is adopted to compare these students’ perceptions with those of their forefathers and those who are living overseas. The findings reveal that today’s Vietnamese business students may not totally agree with their parents and those living abroad about the relevance and applicability of all the norms and values. Nonetheless, most norms and values are still properly regarded since they have strong roots in the history and tradition of the Vietnamese people. Educators can use these norms and values, probably via idioms and famous sayings, to give their students the proper and necessary understanding and mindset about the characteristics of a good business person and the consumer market. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Business Education; Idioms; Norms; Values; Vietnam

Title: Knowledge Transformation and Innovation in Global Society: Perspective in a Changing Asia
Affiliations: National Economics University, Vietnam, Viet Nam; Kagoshima Prefectural College, Kagoshima, Japan; National Economics University, Vietnam, Viet Nam; Rikkyo University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Hoa Tran, Thi, National Economics University, Vietnam, Viet Nam; Shioji, Hiromi, Kagoshima Prefectural College, Kagoshima, Japan; Le, Huong Thu Thi, School of Business, National Economics University, Vietnam, Viet Nam; Hayashi, Takabumi, Rikkyo University, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This is the first book to fully explain the changing management and business models in the current era of important new developments in knowledge and information occurring all over the world. The research and its outcomes presented here focus especially on diverse cases from emerging countries in East Asia, where local companies face similar technological change. The pandemic has seriously changed people’s lives and affected the development of society as a whole, while digital technologies have become even more greatly in demand. Those are very difficult to fit into traditional management models created decades ago, however. For the successful implementation of such a transition, new paradigms, models, and technologies for the transformation of control systems are needed. To meet that need, a new paradigm to bring about innovation under the new knowledge transformation system is required. This book presents the experiences of beginning such a knowledge transformation inEast Asian countries. Despite the fact that the countries are in the same geographical region, their experiences are quite diverse, determined by cultural, historical, religious, and psychological factors. These differences appear not only in such important areas as R&D processes, but also in production, finance, HR management, and marketing. Readers will find innovative solutions for the transformation of management in the new knowledge transformation system that is the focus of this book. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Business Eco-systems; Digital Hybrid Value Chain; Inclusive Business Innovation; It-bpo; It-business Process Outsourcing; It-led Business Management; New Industrial Development Path

Authors: J.P., Juanga-Labayen, Jeanger P.; I.V., Labayen, Ildefonso Villavecer; M.T., Montalbo-Lomboy, Melissa Tababa; M.T.T., Ngo, My Thi Tra; P.V.M., Doan, Phuong Vu Mai
Author full names: Juanga-Labayen, Jeanger P. (16028473100); Labayen, Ildefonso Villavecer (58945542400); Montalbo-Lomboy, Melissa Tababa (22951520000); Ngo, My Thi Tra (57216808798); Doan, Phuong Vu Mai (58097017300)
Title: Emerging Green Technologies for Organic Waste Management
Affiliations: Carlos Hilado Memorial State University, Talisay, Philippines; Technological University of the Philippines, Manila, Philippines; Rowan University, Glassboro, United States; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Rowan University, Glassboro, United States; Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Juanga-Labayen, Jeanger P., Carlos Hilado Memorial State University, Talisay, Philippines; Labayen, Ildefonso Villavecer, Technological University of the Philippines, Manila, Philippines; Montalbo-Lomboy, Melissa Tababa, Rowan University, Glassboro, United States; Ngo, My Thi Tra, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Doan, Phuong Vu Mai, Rowan University, Glassboro, United States, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: Sustainable industrial growth requires a sustainable supply of resources and the utilization of the generated waste. Organic waste has been recognized as a valuable resource; however, organic waste treatment remains a global challenge in the 21st century. State-of-the-art treatment technologies designed for organic waste to combat resource depletion and mitigate global warming are vital. Organic waste streams generated by industries, agriculture, and municipal solid waste including human waste are the major sources of waste that pose environmental issues. The application of green technology for organic waste treatment is a sustainable approach to mitigating climate change and conserving our depleting resources. Emerging green technologies such as fermentation, anaerobic digestion, vermicomposting, and bioremediation are widely utilized in transforming organic waste into sustainable resources. Such valuable resources include bioplastics, biofuels, and biofertilizers. A sustainable approach in organic waste management by integrating green technology is a close-loop method, which supports a circular economy. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.V., Ha, Nguyen Viet; T.N., Tuan Kiet, Tran Nguyen; B.N., Thanh Binh, Bui Ngoc; N.M., Tri, Nguyen Minh; T.T., Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi; M.M.T., Tsuru, Masato M.T.
Author full names: Ha, Nguyen Viet (24343793500); Tuan Kiet, Tran Nguyen (59007134000); Thanh Binh, Bui Ngoc (59007085200); Tri, Nguyen Minh (58402907800); Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi (57211186664); Tsuru, Masato M.T. (7005093872)
Title: Real-Time In-Band Network Link Loss Detection With Programmable Data Plane
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ha, Nguyen Viet, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tuan Kiet, Tran Nguyen, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thanh Binh, Bui Ngoc, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tri, Nguyen Minh, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thao Nguyen, Tran Thi, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tsuru, Masato M.T., Kyushu Institute of Technology, Kitakyushu, Japan
Abstract: Quality commitment is essential in providing network services and applications to clients. The packet loss in the network, due to link corruption and congestion, causes the performance degradation of many network services, affecting the application experience. Packet loss often happens in both lossy networks like wireless networks and reliable local networks like data center networks. The previous papers proposed methods to estimate the link loss (packet loss on link) and feedback to the controller via the OpenFlow. However, the feedback process passively depends on the scheduled OpenFlow Flow-Stat packet sent from the controller, resulting in late detection and response to the loss events. Besides, the accumulated loss in a path with multiple nodes causes a less accurate estimation at the node far from the measurement host due to insufficient probe packets. Therefore, this paper proposes a new scheme based on programmable data plane-enabled switches, such as the P4-enabled switch, to actively calculate the link loss and send the feedback to the controller. It also ensures the total probe packet at all links always equals the one that departs from the measurement host by supplementing the probe packet to compensate for the loss in the previous link. The simulation on ns-3 shows the efficiency of the proposed scheme in achieving a good accuracy estimation and a short response time to the network state change. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.N., Duong, Anh Ngoc; C., Phan, Chianh; R., Nakamoto, Ryuichi; H., Nguyen, Hathu; Y., Matsui, Yoshiki
Author full names: Duong, Anh Ngoc (58988902200); Phan, Chianh (36998615600); Nakamoto, Ryuichi (58777856800); Nguyen, Hathu (57201549194); Matsui, Yoshiki (7402827345)
Title: Market knowledge impacts on performances through front end process: empirical evidence from manufacturing plants across countries
Source title: International Journal of Productivity and Quality Management
Affiliations: Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The Open University of Japan, Chiba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Duong, Anh Ngoc, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Phan, Chianh, School of Business Administration, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nakamoto, Ryuichi, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Nguyen, Hathu, School of Business Administration, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Matsui, Yoshiki, Faculty of Liberal Arts, The Open University of Japan, Chiba, Japan
Abstract: This study investigates how manufacturing plants explore market knowledge to enhance their competitive position in global competition, particularly the impact of customer knowledge and supplier knowledge on organisational performance via the front end (FE) process. This study applies structural equation modelling to analyse databases collected from 2013 to 2016 in 220 manufacturing plants across 13 countries in the High Performance Manufacturing (HPM) Project Round 4 framework. Empirical evidence supports that the FE process would act as a mediator from input, customer or supplier market knowledge to output, organisational performance (including the success of new product development (NPD), quality, and customer satisfaction). Notably, customer market knowledge and supplier market knowledge play the primary source in the FE process in Western and Eastern countries. Empirical evidence suggests that manufacturing managers should consider customer and supplier market knowledge to enhance NPD success, quality, and customer satisfaction. Future research might explore the integration of customer and supplier market knowledge or the impact of improvements in IT technology on the FE process. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Customer Market Knowledge; Customer Satisfaction; Front End Process; Market Knowledge; New Product Development; Npd; Quality; Supplier Market Knowledge

Authors: T.X.T., Pham, Thoa Xuan Thi; K., Yokozawa, Kodo; N.N., Anh, Nguyen Ngoc
Author full names: Pham, Thoa Xuan Thi (57221293729); Yokozawa, Kodo (57217983827); Anh, Nguyen Ngoc (57216193031)
Title: The influences of boundary spanning capabilities and long–term orientation on opportunism in inter–firm relationships
Affiliations: FPT University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Thoa Xuan Thi, Faculty of Business, FPT University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yokozawa, Kodo, Department of Business Administration, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; Anh, Nguyen Ngoc, Department of Social Sciences, Economic and Management, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Opportunism is a common issue in inter–firm relationships, which increases transaction costs, impairs firm performance and supply chain efficiency, and deteriorates relationship quality. Previous studies have intensively investigated factors influencing opportunism but overfocusing on the organisational level. Recently, supply chain researchers have called for identifying factors influencing opportunism at the individual level to gain a more comprehensive understanding of opportunism. Based on transaction cost theory, resource dependence theory, and boundary spanning theory, this study seeks to advance the emerging research stream on opportunism at the individual level by investigating how buyer agents’ boundary spanning capabilities and firms’ long–term relationship orientation can help manage supplier agents’ opportunism. Using a cross–sectional data set of 406 buyer agents from manufacturing companies collected from February to April 2021 in Japan, we tested a set of hypotheses through regression and conditional process analyses. Our findings suggest that buyer agents’ strategic communication and firms’ long–term relationship orientation are critical factors that reduce supplier agents’ opportunism. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Boundary Spanning Capability; Inter–firm Relationship; Japan; Long–term Orientation; Opportunism

Authors: H.T., Nguyen-Phung, Hang Thu; N.N., Nthenya, Nahashon Nzioka
Author full names: Nguyen-Phung, Hang Thu (57983679800); Nthenya, Nahashon Nzioka (58192332300)
Title: The causal effect of education on women’s empowerment: evidence from Kenya
Affiliations: Asian Growth Research Institute, Kitakyushu, Japan; Hanoi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen-Phung, Hang Thu, Asian Growth Research Institute, Kitakyushu, Japan, Faculty of Information Technology, Hanoi University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nthenya, Nahashon Nzioka, Graduate School of Economics, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: This paper investigated the impacts of education on women’s empowerment in Kenya using six waves of nationally-representative KDHS data. Our study utilizes the change in educational structure in 1985 as an instrument and finds that women under the new system enhanced their schooling by approximately two years. One year of education prolongs women’s timing of the first birth, decreases female genital mutilation for the first daughter, reduces intimate partner violence, and improves women’s household decision-making. Our findings are robust to several robustness checks. We examined different paths to explain these results, including information exposure, partner matching, and labor market engagement. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N.D.K., Ngo, Nu Dieu Khue; T.Q., Le, Thanh Quynh; R., Tansuchat, Roengchai; T., Nguyen-Mau, Toannguyen; H., Van-Nam, Huynh
Author full names: Ngo, Nu Dieu Khue (57211714263); Le, Thanh Quynh (57431943000); Tansuchat, Roengchai (36085809500); Nguyen-Mau, Toannguyen (57192962077); Van-Nam, Huynh (7003274638)
Title: Evaluating Innovation Capability in Banking Under Uncertainty
Affiliations: Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Ngo, Nu Dieu Khue, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Le, Thanh Quynh, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tansuchat, Roengchai, Faculty of Economics, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand; Nguyen-Mau, Toannguyen, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan; Van-Nam, Huynh, Graduate School of Advanced Science and Technology, Japan Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Nomi, Japan
Abstract: The evaluation of innovation capability (IC) plays a key role in an age of keen competition driven by modern technologies, since it enables organizations to review their innovation management process and to adjust their corresponding innovation policies. Moreover, the IC evaluation is, in fact, a multicriteria process with high uncertainty, since the market environments and competitors' performance are both in a dynamic environment. Therefore, the evaluation of IC under uncertainty is vital to organizations. This study proposes a new integrated method for the evaluation of IC in banking organizations by combining the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) and the evidential reasoning (ER) approach in terms of the Dempster-Shafer theory of evidence. Three Vietnamese banks were used as a case study to demonstrate the applicability and validity of the proposed method. Experts in banking-related fields were invited to determine the relative importance weights of critical innovation management practices (CIMPs) and their sub-CIMPs using the AHP and to score the maturity levels of sub-CIMPs at the evaluated banks. The ER approach was then applied to generate aggregated assessments representing the ICs of banks that were finally used for their ranking in terms of IC. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Tseng, Minglang; T.P.T., Tran, Thi Phuong Thuy; M., Fujii, Minoru; M.K., Lim, Ming K.; Y.T., Negash, Yeneneh Tamirat
Author full names: Tseng, Minglang (44261803600); Tran, Thi Phuong Thuy (57218381942); Fujii, Minoru (55738468000); Lim, Ming K. (7201473042); Negash, Yeneneh Tamirat (57212265634)
Title: Modelling hierarchical circular supply chain management enablers in the seafood processing industry in Vietnam under uncertainties
Source title: International Journal of Logistics Research and Applications
Affiliations: Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan; China Medical University Hospital, Taichung, Taiwan; Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia; Asia University College of Management, Taichung, Taiwan; Foreign Trade University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Tseng, Minglang, Institute of Innovation and Circular Economy, Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan, Department of Medical Research, China Medical University Hospital, Taichung, Taiwan, Faculty of Economics and Management, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia; Tran, Thi Phuong Thuy, Asia University College of Management, Taichung, Taiwan, Foreign Trade University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujii, Minoru, Center for Social and Environmental Systems Research, National Institute for Environmental Studies of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Lim, Ming K., Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Negash, Yeneneh Tamirat, Institute of Innovation and Circular Economy, Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan, Asia University, Taichung, Taiwan
Abstract: This study establishes a valid set of circular supply chain management enablers in Vietnam under uncertainties. Circular supply chain management optimises resource utilisation and minimises waste in achieving competitive advantage; however, prior studies failed to build enablers for industrial improvement under qualitative information. This study adopts the fuzzy Delphi method to arrive at a valid group of attributes. Fuzzy set theory deals with the uncertainties from qualitative data, and fuzzy interpretive structural modelling builds the hierarchical structure under uncertainties. The best-worst method confirms the consistencies. This study stipulates a four-level hierarchical structure in the seafood processing industry. The results show that organisational capability and agility, technological advancement and economic benefit are dominant aspects. Commitment of leadership and managerial support, suppliers’ collaboration, firm culture, readiness for organisational change and sustainability concept integration are top criteria for industrial improvement. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Best-worst Method; Circular Supply Chain Management Enablers; Dynamic Capability View; Fuzzy Set Theory; Interpretive Structural Modelling; Triple Bottom Line

Authors: T.L., Pham, Thi Lam; I., Saizen, Izuru
Author full names: Pham, Thi Lam (58679557200); Saizen, Izuru (15053715500)
Title: Coastal fishers’ livelihood adaptations to extreme weather events: an analysis of household strategies in Quang Ngai Province, Vietnam
Affiliations: East Asia University of Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Thi Lam, East Asia University of Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Saizen, Izuru, Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Extreme weather events (EWEs) pose significant threats to fishery-based livelihoods in Quang Ngai (QN) Province, Vietnam. This study describes the types of livelihood adaptations (LAs) that coastal fishers in QN have practiced in response to EWEs and find the varieties in these adaptation strategy choices. In this study, we investigated livelihood adaptation strategies in coastal areas through a household survey and analysis of the collected data using MS Excel. Two sample strategies were used, stratified and random sampling, to select 229 coastal fishers from 11 communes; and data are collected through designed questionnaires. The current study employed statistical disaggregation and comparative methods to analyze coastal fishers’ adaptation strategy choices in QN Province. A range of adaptation strategies were identified consisting of five reactive LAs and eight anticipatory LAs practiced differently by coastal fishers. Among the eight anticipatory LAs, discontinuing production for a certain time is a novel adaptation in QN Province. In addition, a divergence in conducting LAs by production forms was found. On-sand farming and offshore fishers invest in advanced technologies and facilities as adaptive measures. By contrast, fishers who farm in estuaries, lagoons, and nearshore fishing fishers are more likely to change and diversify their jobs. The study’s key findings about livelihood adaptation measures and their differences are significant for improving coastal fisher’s livelihoods in Vietnam. Any efforts at local and national levels in developing mitigation strategies for the impact of EWEs may consider the coastal fisher’s adaptation choices. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Funding Texts: This work was funded by Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) through the Project for Human Resources Development Scholarship by the Japanese Grant Aid (JDS). The data collection for this study was supported by the Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies (GSGES), Kyoto University, Japan.

Authors: P.A., Mantello, Peter A.; M., Ho, Manhtung; M.H., Nguyen, Minh Hoang; Q.H., Vuong, Quan Hoang
Author full names: Mantello, Peter A. (55538758500); Ho, Manhtung (57196438315); Nguyen, Minh Hoang (57205713877); Vuong, Quan Hoang (45161334600)
Title: Machines that feel: behavioral determinants of attitude towards affect recognition technology—upgrading technology acceptance theory with the mindsponge model
Affiliations: Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Social Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Mantello, Peter A., Ritsumeikan Asia Pacific University, Beppu, Japan; Ho, Manhtung, Centre for Interdisciplinary Social Research, Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Institute of Philosophy, Vietnam Academy of Social Sciences, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Minh Hoang, Centre for Interdisciplinary Social Research, Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vuong, Quan Hoang, Centre for Interdisciplinary Social Research, Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The rise of emotional AI signals a new era in human-machine relations where intelligent machines not only feel but also feed on human emotions as statistical fodder with the goal of reshaping our behavior. Unlike many smart technologies, emotion-recognition systems sense, monitor, harvest and analyze data extracted from a person’s non-conscious or psycho-physical state, often without their knowledge or consent. As a far more invasive manner of surveillance capitalism, the technological adoption of emotional AI is problematized by a myriad of legal, ethical, cultural, and scientific issues. To better understand the behavioral factors determining an individual’s attitude towards this emerging technology, we first identify five major tensions that may impinge on adoption. Second, we extend the Technological Acceptance Model (TAM) (Davis, 1989) model with insights from the mindsponge model of information filtering (Vuong and Napier, 2015) along with quantitative affordances offered by the Bayesian computational approach. Our analysis was conducted based on a multi-national dataset surveying perceptions of 1015 young adults (age 18–27) regarding emotional AI applications and their socio-cultural characteristics such as income, region, religiosity, and home country politics. These characteristics are fed into our Bayesian multi-level models as varying intercepts so that we can systematically measure and compare the effects of various behavioral determinants on the attitudes of respondents towards non-conscious data harvesting by government and private sector actors. Critically, this study finds respondents who feel more familiar with, and perceive more utilities in AI technologies, as well as rate themselves as more restrained from heated arguments on social media, feel less threatened by the practice of non-conscious data harvesting by both government and private sector actors. Our findings offer a fertile platform for further exploration of the intersection between psychology, culture, and emotion-recognition technologies as well as important insights for policymakers wishing to ensure design and regulation of the technology serve the best interests of society. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Funding Texts: This study is part of the project \u201CEmotional AI in Cities: Cross Cultural Lessons from UK and Japan on Designing for an Ethical Life \u201D funded by JST-UKRI Joint Call on Artificial Intelligence and Society (2019) (https://www.jst.go.jp/ristex/hite/en/topics/409.html), Grant No. JPMJRX19H6. The authors would like to thank all the APU faculty members that helped us distribute the survey. Author Manh-Tung Ho would like to express his sincere gratitude for the support of the SGH Scholarship Foundation.

Authors: L.T.Q., Le, Lien Thi Quynh; D., Ho, Dungquoc; T., Inoguchi, Takashi
Author full names: Le, Lien Thi Quynh (57190664749); Ho, Dungquoc (58475112000); Inoguchi, Takashi (26644857700)
Title: Asia’s four regionalisms (Southeast Asia, South Asia, Central Asia and East Asia): a view from multilateral treaties of the United Nations
Affiliations: University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; J. F. Oberlin University, Machida, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Lien Thi Quynh, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Ho, Dungquoc, School of Engineering and Technology, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Inoguchi, Takashi, J. F. Oberlin University, Machida, Japan
Abstract: This study presents a quantitative framework to analyze the engagement of four Asian sub-regions with global issues through their participation in multilateral treaties across various policy areas. The research addresses key questions regarding the speed of Asian states’ involvement in multilateral treaties and their adaptation to these treaties within the United Nations system over time. The approach combines empirical data and conceptualization to ensure a robust evidentiary basis. A dataset comprising 600 major multilateral treaties deposited in the United Nations system, covering diverse global issues, was collected. Additionally, ratification actions from twenty-eight Asian countries were categorized into four sub-regions: East Asia, South Asia, Southeast Asia, and Central Asia. To quantitatively measure states’ engagement with multilateral treaties, the study developed and calculated the Treaty Participation Index for each Asian country and sub-group. In an area predominantly characterized by qualitative research, this paper contributes to the existing literature by providing quantitative and metric findings for comparative analyses of multilateral treaty participation among the four Asian sub-regions, as well as comparisons between Asia and the rest of the world. By analyzing the results, the paper offers an evidence-based assessment of the feasibility of these four regionalisms in Asia, particularly in the context of the transition from international politics to the paradigm of global politics. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
